title: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’ and ‘Scary Stories’
description: “Mad Max: Fury Road” airs on Syfy. And the recent movie adaptation of “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark” is on Showtime.
content: MAD MAX: FURY ROAD (2015) 9 p.m. on Syfy. In a recent interview with The New York Times, Charlize Theron looked back on her experience shooting this “Mad Max” sequel. “I feel a mixture of extreme joy that we achieved what we did, and I also get a little bit of a hole in my stomach,” she said. Anyone who’s seen the movie will have a sense that shooting it would have been arduous: It revolves around a high-speed desert chase, with characters vaulting between enormous, rusty vehicles cobbled together from spare parts. The main players — the driver Furiosa (Theron) and the warrior Max (Tom Hardy) — are in perpetual motion, threatened by a crazed leader, Immortan Joe (Hugh Keays-Byrne), and an army of his underlings. “The biggest thing that was driving that entire production was fear,” Theron said. “I was incredibly scared, because I’d never done anything like it.”

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: 7 Takeaways From Mary Trump’s Book About Her Uncle Donald
description: Growing up Trump wasn’t easy. There were feuds, grudges and spanking with a wooden spoon. Now, there’s the burden of the name.
content: In the prologue of “Too Much and Never Enough,” Mary Trump writes: “The media failed to notice that not one member of Donald’s family, apart from his children, his son-in-law and his current wife, said a word in support of him during the entire campaign.” That doesn’t mean they had no opinions. The daughter of the president’s older brother, Freddy, who died in 1981, now shares some of hers — not just by airing the family’s dirty laundry, but by washing and folding it, too. (Mary Trump is a clinical psychologist whose diagnoses for her uncle are as varied and extensive as the fast food buffet he offered the Clemson Tigers when they visited the White House in 2019.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: In New Book, Trump’s Niece Describes Him as Still a Child, Seeking Attention
description: The release of Mary L. Trump’s “Too Much and Never Enough” has been widely anticipated.
content: President Trump’s niece describes him in a much-awaited tell-all book as a child in an adult’s body, someone psychologically brutalized and damaged by his “sociopath” father and who developed defenses of anger and distrust to mask his own chronic insecurities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj
title: Santiago Manuin, Indigenous Leader in Peru, Dies at 63
description: Mr. Manuin fought for the rights of Indigenous people and the protection of the Amazon. He survived a gunshot wound from a 2009 police crackdown, but died last week of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Ida Haendel, Violin Virtuoso With ‘Fire and Ice’ in Her Playing, Dies
description: A link to the early-20th-century school of violin playing, Ms. Haendel was a noted champion of the concertos of Britten, Walton and Sibelius.
content: Ida Haendel, the Polish-born prodigy with a fiery sound and unassailable technique who became one of the foremost violinists of her generation,  died on July 1 in Pembroke Park, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Chicks Are Done Caring What People Think
description: The trio formerly known as the Dixie Chicks is returning with its first album in 14 years, at peace with an industry that’s never made nice.
content: The women formerly known as the Dixie Chicks have survived the good old boys of country music, a legal battle with their record label, a feud with a president and arguably the first attempted cancellation of the internet era. As they plotted their comeback — writing their first album together in 14 years — they decided to have a little bit of fun with their reputation. So they called up restaurants across America with menu items named after the band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Drivers Are Hitting Protesters as Memes of Car Attacks Spread
description: In recent days, one person was killed in Seattle and two people were injured in Bloomington, Ind. Dozens of similar incidents have occurred across the United States.
content: The driver of a red Toyota first stopped, then unexpectedly accelerated into a crowd of dispersing demonstrators in Bloomington, Ind., on Monday night, injuring two of them in the latest of a disturbing rash of vehicular attacks targeting protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Lady Antebellum Sues the Singer Lady A Over Name Change
description: The platinum-selling country group’s new name was already being used by a blues singer. Now they’re asking a court to affirm “a trademark we have held for many years.”
content: When the country trio Lady Antebellum announced last month that it would change its Civil War-referencing band name to Lady A out of respect for Black people, the group credited the widespread protests against police brutality for revealing “blind spots we didn’t even know existed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Downward Dog
description: Chase Dittrich makes his New York Times Crossword debut by messing with his keyboard.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Another debut this week! Chase Dittrich joins the club with a puzzle that made me smile and really appreciate computer keyboard shortcuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Arizona Is #1, Bahrain Is #4
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: There is no country in the world where confirmed coronavirus cases are growing as rapidly as they are in Arizona, Florida or South Carolina. The Sun Belt has become the global virus capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Mainers Are ‘Disappointed,’ Too, Susan Collins
description: Maybe we’ve been expecting too much of her all along.
content: As I filled out my absentee ballot for the Maine primary, I was overcome with a familiar sense of dejection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alejandra Rosa and Frances Robles
title: Pandemic Plunges Puerto Rico Into Yet Another Dire Emergency
description: The island has had to weather a hurricane, a political crisis and earthquakes, but those crises did not lead to the widespread unemployment caused by the response to the coronavirus pandemic.
content: SAN JUAN, P.R. — With hundreds of thousands of people suddenly out of jobs in Puerto Rico, Luciano Soto, a tour guide who has not worked in nearly four months, wanted to be first in line at the Puerto Rico Convention Center, now outfitted as an unemployment office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Miriam Jordan
title: Harvard and M.I.T. Sue to Stop Trump Visa Rules for Foreign Students
description: Universities opposed a policy that would require students to take at least one in-person class or be denied permission to study in the United States.
content: Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology sued the Trump administration in federal court on Wednesday, seeking to block a directive that would strip foreign college students of their visas if the courses they take this fall are entirely online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donté Stallworth
title: I Played in the N.F.L. It Needs Way More Than a Black Anthem.
description: If the league wants to show its commitment to its players, it should hire and promote more Black coaches and executives.
content: WASHINGTON — In response to the Black Lives Matter protests, the N.F.L. has decided to play “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” known as the Black national anthem, in Week 1 of its coming season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Islamists Block Construction of First Hindu Temple in Islamabad
description: The government hailed the temple as a sign of Pakistan’s growing tolerance under Prime Minister Imran Khan. But pressure from clerics mounted, and the government gave in.
content: A Hindu temple planned for Islamabad, the city’s first, was supposed to be a symbol of tolerance. Instead, violence and controversy have turned it into an emblem of Pakistan’s troubled relationship with its religious minorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Feldman Barrett
title: College Courses Online Are Disappointing. Here’s How to Fix Them.
description: No one wants to pay $30,000 per semester for the current experience.
content: Millions of families with college-age children face a difficult choice. As school after school announces that it will welcome students back to campus this fall, many classes — perhaps most — may continue to be held online. A survey of college students in the spring found that about 75 percent were disappointed with the online learning experience during the lockdown. Is it worth paying as much as $30,000 per semester for that sort of education?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Court Ruling in Monaco Ends One Piece of a $2 Billion Art Dispute
description: The case against Yves Bouvier, a Swiss businessman who helped the Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev buy 38 artworks, was dismissed.
content: A long-running dispute, between Yves Bouvier, a Swiss businessman who sold $2 billion worth of artworks, and Dmitry Rybolovlev, the Russian billionaire who bought them, took a decisive step in Mr. Bouvier’s favor Wednesday when a Monaco court upheld a lower court’s ruling to dismiss the criminal investigation against him because the prosecution of him had been unfair.

content: One of the go-to mantras from the Gregg Popovich coaching handbook is a leaguewide credo now. No one in the N.B.A., as Popovich has been saying in San Antonio for years, wants to be caught “skipping steps” as the league begins the most challenging undertaking in its history.

content: ISTANBUL — Since it was built in the sixth century, changing hands from empire to empire, Hagia Sophia has been a Byzantine cathedral, a mosque under the Ottomans and finally a museum, making it one of the world’s most potent symbols of Christian-Muslim rivalry and of Turkey’s more recent devotion to secularism.

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: All in the Family Dynamics: Donald Trump’s Niece on the President’s Clan
description: In “Too Much and Never Enough,” Mary L. Trump says her uncle is turning this country “into a macro version of my malignantly dysfunctional family.”
content: Robert Trump, baby brother of Donald Trump, has had a curious turn in the spotlight these last couple of weeks, as he has repeatedly tried to prevent the publication of “Too Much and Never Enough,” a new memoir by his and the president’s niece, Mary L. Trump. In the book, it turns out that Uncle Rob has only a bit part to play — the youngest child of five who took the path of least resistance, sliding into the executive chair of his father’s business, a mostly passive bystander to the central drama between Donald and Mary’s father, Freddy. Still, Mary doesn’t strip Rob of all personality. She remembers him as a teenager, not much older than she was, leaning against the refrigerator as he peeled back the foil on a block of Philadelphia cream cheese and ate it “as if it were a candy bar.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Review: ‘Little Voice’ Is a Twee Musical Fairy Tale
description: If you’re looking for something earnest and coronavirus-free, the Apple TV+ series from Sara Bareilles and Jessie Nelson may be perfectly timed.
content: If you’re particularly hungry to escape current realities, and have a susceptibility to industrial-strength sentimentality wrapped in tastefully autumnal lighting, then “Little Voice” on Apple TV+ might appeal to you. A half-hour dramedy premiering Friday about an aspiring singer-songwriter who tends bar, teaches music and walks dogs on the suspiciously clean streets of New York, it’s coronavirus-free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Beach House’ Review: No Fun Memories for These Vacationers
description: By the time it dawns on a couple that “maybe it wasn’t such a great idea to go to the beach,” it’s way too late.
content: Two college-age hotties, Randall and Emily (Noah Le Gros and Liana Liberato), have won the jackpot — a romantic getaway to his father’s beautiful, empty house, with direct access to a beautiful, empty beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney World Draws Excitement and Incredulity as Reopening Nears
description: The mega-resort will welcome back visitors on Saturday even as coronavirus cases in Florida remain high. In doing so, Disney steps into a politicized debate.
content: Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., will reopen on Saturday, and Disney has been posting marketing videos online to highlight the safety procedures it has designed to protect visitors and employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Brad Plumer
title: Is This the End of New Pipelines?
description: Defeats at three projects reflect increasingly sophisticated legal challenges, shifting economics and growing demands by states to fight climate change.
content: They are among the nation’s most significant infrastructure projects: More than 9,000 miles of oil and gas pipelines in the United States are currently being built or expanded, and another 12,500 miles have been approved or announced — together, almost enough to circle the Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Tammy Duckworth Confronts Nativist Smears From Tucker Carlson
description: Ms. Duckworth, an Illinois senator who is Thai-American and lost both legs fighting in Iraq, has been the target of two nights of attacks from the Fox News host; some were amplified by President Trump.
content: Senator Tammy Duckworth of Illinois, a Thai-American Democrat who lost both of her legs fighting in the Iraq war and is now a potential vice-presidential nominee, was targeted with nativist smears for the second night in a row on Tuesday by Fox News’s Tucker Carlson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain Plans Incentives to Bring Its Workers Back
description: Fearing layoffs as a furlough program expires, the government is prodding businesses to coax their staff members to return — and consumers to eat out.
content: The British government, facing a potential avalanche of layoffs in the fall, announced a host of tax and spending measures on Wednesday to preserve and create jobs in Britain as the nation reopens its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Ninja Played Fortnite on YouTube, and the Gaming World Lost Its Mind
description: The buzz that Tyler Blevins, also known as Ninja, generated by streaming on a new platform showed the power famous content creators have in the video game industry.
content: When Tyler Blevins, who is better known in the video gaming world as Ninja, posted a cryptic tweet on Wednesday that seemed to hint at some sort of announcement, his ardent fans thought he might reveal the kind of big-dollar contract one would expect from baseball or basketball stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Carey
title: What Harvard and Your Local Commuter College Now Have in Common
description: For colleges in the middle of the pack, the financial calculus during the pandemic looks very different, with in-person classes on campus a way to survive.
content: This week, bowing to the reality of a raging pandemic, Harvard announced that “all course instruction (undergraduate and graduate) for the 2020-21 academic year will be delivered online.” Some students, mostly freshmen, will be allowed to live on campus, but even they will learn remotely from socially distanced dorms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: ‘Far Side’ Cartoonist Gary Larson Shares First New Work in 25 Years
description: In a note on his website, Mr. Larson thanked a clogged pen for pushing him to create digital cartoons on a tablet. “I’m just exploring, experimenting, and trying stuff,” he said. “New Stuff.”
content: The “Far Side” cartoonist Gary Larson surprised fans this week with three new cartoons, 25 years after his retirement and months after he teased his return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Azi Paybarah
title: Driver Charged With Vehicular Homicide in Death of Seattle Protester
description: The driver, Dawit Kelete, 27, struck two demonstrators with his car early Saturday, one of whom later died, prosecutors said.
content: A Seattle man who the authorities said drove into a protest on a closed section of Interstate 5 over the weekend, killing one demonstrator, was charged on Wednesday with vehicular homicide, vehicular assault and reckless driving.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 8, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 8, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about the lack of coronavirus testing capacity in U.S. cities described incorrectly the details of recent testing in Wuhan, China. The rapid testing of 6.5 million people was part of a campaign to screen the city’s entire population, not in response to a new outbreak. And the testing took place in May, not June.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The Magazine’s fiction issue was inspired by Giovanni Boccaccio’s book of tales, written as the plague swept Florence in the 14th century.

title: Stocks drop as Wall Street cools off after five-day rally.
description: Stocks on Wall Street dipped on Tuesday, cooling off after a five-day rally, as new economic data for Europe forecast a grim outlook for the year and cases of Covid-19 continued to spread.
content: Stocks on Wall Street dipped on Tuesday, cooling off after a five-day rally, as new economic data for Europe forecast a grim outlook for the year and cases of Covid-19 continued to spread.

title: Over 180 Bodies Found Dumped in Burkina Faso Town, Report Says
description: For months, terrified residents of Djibo, a town in the West African nation, kept discovering corpses of men who had been shot, blindfolded and bound. They blame the military.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — The bodies of at least 180 men thought to have been killed by security forces have been found dumped in fields, by roadsides and under bridges in a town in the West African country of Burkina Faso over the past eight months, witnesses told human rights researchers.

title: Island Heights, N.J.: A ‘Magical Place’ That’s a Step Out of Time
description: Founded in the 19th century as a Methodist camp meeting site, this Ocean County borough retains an old-fashioned feeling, even as newcomers move in.
content: Residents and visitors are back on the boardwalk for sunset strolls, the pickleball courts are open and white sails have been dotting the shoreline of Island Heights, N.J., for some time. But it wasn’t until this week, when the Island Heights Yacht Club’s junior sailing program started up again, that something of a sense of normalcy would return to this Ocean County borough on the banks of Toms River.

author: By Marie Fazio
title: New Red Algae Are Threatening Hawaii’s Coral Reefs, Scientists Say
description: The recently discovered species covers coral in a thick layer and suffocates it. Scientists don’t know where it came from.
content: On a routine trip to monitor ocean wildlife near the northwestern Hawaiian Islands in 2016, researchers noticed small patches of red algae they had never seen before growing on the coral reefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Japan Flooding Deaths Rise to 58, With More Rain on Horizon
description: Tens of thousands of troops, police officers and other rescue workers have worked their way through mud and debris in the hardest-hit riverside towns to evacuate residents.
content: For more than a week, Japan has been battered by floods driven by torrential rains, spurring widespread evacuations and the deaths of at least 58 people by Wednesday. Many people remained missing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mexican Leader Vows ‘Dignity’ at Trump’s Side; Critics Fear Humiliation
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, visiting the White House Wednesday, has avoided fighting the Trump administration. Critics say he is too willing to bend to the American president’s will.
content: Before heading out for his first state visit to the United States, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the firebrand president of Mexico known for excoriating his foes in long-winded tirades, made a surprising promise to his people.

title: Chief Justice Roberts Was Hospitalized Last Month With a Head Injury
description: A court spokeswoman said the chief justice had fallen while walking for exercise and blamed dehydration.
content: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. sustained a head injury last month that required a night at the hospital, a spokeswoman for the Supreme Court said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What Does it Mean to be ‘At Home’ These Days?
description: People are experiencing the reopening of the country in different ways in different regions. They are responding to it differently, too.
content: Welcome. I write from home because home is where I work, but I’m not always at home any longer. I’ve been to a hardware store this week, a pizzeria, a convenience store and the chandlery for a length of rope, which for someone who’s only been to the supermarket like five times since March seems like a lot of progress. This weekend I’m going to a bookstore. I want to read “Crooked Hallelujah,” by Kelli Jo Ford. I might hit the beach to do it.

title: What’s at the Bottom of a Confederate Monument? It Could Be a Time Capsule
description: Workers removing a monument in North Carolina found a deteriorated time capsule from 1894. Inside were objects said to belong to Robert E. Lee, though some historians doubt their legitimacy.
content: As North Carolina crew workers picked away at a 75-foot Confederate monument on the Capitol grounds in Raleigh — using a crane to lift it piece by piece — they found something else underneath.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Hosts Mexican President to Celebrate Trade Deal
description: President Trump and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico marked the start of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement on Wednesday. It replaced the North American Free Trade Agreement.

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: On Some Planes, Empty Rows While Passengers Crowd Together
description: Airlines vowed to bring social distancing to the air. In practice, some are and some aren’t.
content: On a June 30 flight on American Airlines from Dallas to Newark, Joy Gonzalez, an aviation engineer based in Seattle, found herself seated at a window with two older passengers beside her in the middle and aisle seats. In order to gain more social distance, she and the aisle passenger both moved to seats behind them where two rows were empty. But before takeoff, a flight attendant ordered them back to their assigned seats, telling them they had not paid for those exit row seats, which are more expensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rosen and Henry Fountain
title: How Wildfires Make Covid More Dangerous
description: Also this week, our reporter battles wild wind and a leaky air mattress
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter! Join us on Thursday for the debut of Netting Zero, a series of virtual events looking ahead to key international climate negotiations next year. The first panel, Applying Covid-19’s Hard-Earned Lessons to Climate Change, will be moderated by Hannah Fairfield, who leads the Times climate desk. You can register here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Woman Says She Was Fired Because Her Children Disrupted Her Work Calls
description: Drisana Rios of San Diego said in a lawsuit that she lost her job with an insurance brokerage firm after a supervisor complained that her children were being noisy during meetings.
content: A California woman has sued her former employer, saying that she was fired because her young children were making noise during business calls while she was working from home because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: How Could Human Nature Have Become This Politicized?
description: The partisanship of the Trump era has very deep roots.
content: The nation’s faltering attempt to contain the Covid-19 pandemic has revealed once again the role of political partisanship in every aspect of American society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Altmann and Bryan W. Van Norden
title: Was This Ancient Taoist the First Philosopher of Disability?
description: Zhuangzi pushed back against the idea that “normal” is good and difference is bad 2,500 years ago.
content: In one of his philosophical parables, the Taoist philosopher Zhuangzi (fourth century B.C.) describes a man he calls Splay-limb Shu. This man’s “chin is sunk in his belly,” Zhuangzi writes. “His shoulders are above his head, and pinched together so they point to the sky. His five organs are on top, his thighs tight against his ribs.” In Zhuangzi’s era as in our own, most people would consider Splay-limb Shu to be unfortunate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Does Zuckerberg Understand How the Right to Free Speech Works?
description: A new audit warns that Facebook may be “driving people toward self-reinforcing echo chambers of extremism.”
content: It’s time for Mark Zuckerberg to really start listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: I No Longer Believe in a Jewish State
description: For decades I argued for separation between Israelis and Palestinians. Now, I can imagine a Jewish home in an equal state.
content: I was 22 in 1993 when Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat shook hands on the White House lawn to officially begin the peace process that many hoped would create a Palestinian state alongside Israel. I’ve been arguing for a two-state solution — first in late-night bull sessions, then in articles and speeches — ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shoshanna Saxe and Kristen MacAskill
title: Stop Building More Roads
description: There’s a right way to do infrastructure. Why does America get it wrong?
content: Joe Biden and Donald Trump may not agree on much, but one thing unites them, and it’s no small matter: Both support investing trillions of dollars in a nationwide infrastructure campaign. Both recognize, in their own way, the power of such spending to create jobs and revitalize communities, and invest in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: ‘Ai Weiwei: Yours Truly’ Review: On the Irony of Personal Freedom
description: This documentary from Cheryl Haines about Ai, a Chinese artist and activist, explores the tension between the idea of liberty and the fate of those who pursue it.
content: The irony of personal freedom is that those who fight for it are robbed of their own. “Ai Weiwei: Yours Truly” explores the tension between the idea of liberty and the fate of those in pursuit of it by following the Chinese artist and activist Ai Weiwei as he creates @Large, an ambitious site-specific exhibition on Alcatraz Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Charles Booker Says Progressives Should ‘Show Up and Listen’ to Deep Red Districts
description: Mr. Booker, who narrowly lost a Democratic Senate primary in Kentucky, talked about how to get rural voters on board with a progressive message, saying structural inequality affects all people who feel left behind.
content: For most of his Senate campaign in Kentucky, Charles Booker was considered a long shot. He was running in a Democratic primary against Amy McGrath, a former Marine fighter pilot who had the support of the party’s establishment and had raised over $40 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Houston Mayor Cancels Texas G.O.P. Convention, Calling It ‘Public Health Risk’
description: Mayor Sylvester Turner said the large gathering of Republican officials amid a worsening pandemic would put many people at risk. Party officials said they were exploring a legal challenge.
content: HOUSTON — Local outcry had grown for weeks over plans by the Texas Republican Party to hold its convention in Houston in the middle of one of the nation’s worst coronavirus outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Gillian R. Brassil
title: Stanford Permanently Cuts 11 Sports Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
description: The university said in a statement that it faced a $70 million shortfall over the next three years.
content: Stanford University, which has built the most successful broad-based athletic department in the country, said on Wednesday that its model was financially unsustainable in part because of the coronavirus pandemic and that it would permanently drop 11 sports to help offset what it projected would be at least a $70 million deficit over the next three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Noah Weiland
title: Coronavirus Surge in Tulsa ‘More Than Likely’ Linked to Trump Rally
description: Dr. Bruce Dart, the director of the Tulsa Health Department, said Tulsa County had reported nearly 500 new cases of Covid-19 in the past two days.
content: A surge in coronavirus cases in and around Tulsa, Okla., is probably connected to the campaign rally President Trump held there last month, the city’s top health official said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Ady Barkan Endorses Joe Biden for President
description: The endorsement by Mr. Barkan, an activist who supports “Medicare for all,” signaled that some progressives were increasingly willing to back Mr. Biden.
content: Ady Barkan, the prominent liberal activist and advocate for “Medicare for all,” is endorsing Joseph R. Biden Jr. for president, in a sign that some progressives who opposed Mr. Biden in the Democratic primary race are increasingly willing to actively support him against President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman
title: Brooks Brothers, Founded in 1818, Files for Bankruptcy
description: The retailer, which has dressed all but four U.S. presidents, will close 51 U.S. stores as it looks for a buyer.
content: Brooks Brothers, the retailer known for dressing the great and good of the United States since 1818, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday, buckling under the pressure from the coronavirus pandemic after years of faltering sales as customers embraced more casual apparel and sales shifted online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines Could Furlough 36,000 Workers as Virus Cases Soar
description: The airline warned workers that they could lose their jobs because demand for travel remains weak and appears to be falling again as infections rise.
content: United Airlines said on Wednesday that it could furlough as many as 36,000 employees, or nearly 40 percent of its global work force, this fall if travel remained weak and more workers did not accept concessions like reduced hours or buyout and early retirement packages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Hong Kong, U.S. schools, Hagia Sophia: here’s what you need to know.
content: Radio Television Hong Kong, the territory’s public broadcaster, has fearlessly reported on police misconduct and China’s crackdown on the Uighurs, asking tough questions to top officials. But under the new national security law, its journalists have been feeling the pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerry Mullany
title: Hong Kong Bans Protest Song and Other Political Expression at Schools
description: Singing “Glory to Hong Kong,” posting slogans and forming human chains as a form of protest are banned under new guidelines issued by the city’s education secretary.
content: Hong Kong’s education secretary on Wednesday banned students from singing the protest anthem “Glory to Hong Kong,” posting slogans with political messages or forming human chains, saying “the schools are obliged to stop” such activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Kim Barker
title: New Transcripts Detail Last Moments for George Floyd
description: “They’ll kill me. They’ll kill me,” Mr. Floyd pleaded, according to a body camera transcript in court filings by a former officer who wants the charges against him dismissed.
content: George Floyd’s dying moments have played on an endless loop, horrifying the world and prompting a spasm of street protests, but newly released evidence reveals an even more desperate scene than previously known in the moments before an officer pressed his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Grave Shortages of Protective Gear Flare Again as Covid Cases Surge
description: Five months into the pandemic, the U.S. still hasn’t solved the problem. The dearth of supplies is affecting a broad array of health facilities, renewing pleas for White House intervention.
content: As coronavirus cases surge across the country, hospitals, nursing homes and private medical practices are facing a problem many had hoped would be resolved by now: a dire shortage of respirator masks, isolation gowns and disposable gloves that protect front-line medical workers from infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Ivy League Places All Sports on Hold Until January
description: The league’s decision could be influential for other university presidents as they consider how to handle the coronavirus pandemic. It is the first Division I conference to suspend football for the fall.
content: The Ivy League presidents placed all sports on hold Wednesday until at least January, making it the first Division I conference that will not play football as scheduled in the fall because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: Robinhood Has Lured Young Traders, Sometimes With Devastating Results
description: Its users buy and sell the riskiest financial products and do so more frequently than customers at other retail brokerage firms, but their inexperience can lead to staggering losses.
content: Richard Dobatse, a Navy medic in San Diego, dabbled infrequently in stock trading. But his behavior changed in 2017 when he signed up for Robinhood, a trading app that made buying and selling stocks simple and seemingly free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Study of 17 Million Identifies Crucial Risk Factors for Coronavirus Deaths
description: The largest study yet confirms that race, ethnicity, age and gender can raise a person’s chances of dying from Covid-19.
content: An analysis of more than 17 million people in England — the largest study of its kind, according to its authors — has pinpointed a bevy of factors that can raise a person’s chances of dying from Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times
